section.title: Linear Independence
section.introduction: The concept of linear independence is crucial to linear algebra.

subsection.title: Linear Independence
subsection.definition:
Otherwise, \set{\vec{v}_1, \dots, \vec{v}_n} is linearly dependent. In other words, \set{\vec{v}_1, \dots, \vec{v}_n} is linearly dependent if there exists a_1, \dots, a_n, not all zero, such that,
a_1 \vec{v}_1 + \dots + a_n \vec{v}_n = \vec{0}
subsection.p: The zero linear combination a_1 \vec{v}_1 + \dots + a_n \vec{v}_n where a_1 = \dots = a_n = 0 is called the trivial linear combination. Any other linear combination is called non-trivial.

example.title: A single vector
example.p: A set containing a single vector \set{\vec{v}} is linearly independent if and only if \vec{v} is non-zero. This is because the equation a\vec{v} = \vec{0} has only the trivial solution a = 0 if \vec{v} \neq \vec{0}. If \vec{v} = \vec{0}, then a\vec{0} = \vec{0} has non-trivial solutions (any non-zero value for a).

subsection.example:
Set with two vectors
Consider a set with two vectors \set{\vec{v}_1, \vec{v}_2}, and consider the equation,
a \vec{v}_1 + b\vec{v}_2 = \vec{0}
If \vec{v}_1, \vec{v}_2 are linearly dependent, then at least one of a, b are non-zero. If say a \neq 0, then by solving for \vec{v}_1,
\vec{v}_1 = -\frac{b}{a} \vec{v}_2
In other words, \vec{v}_1 is a scalar multiple of \vec{v}_2. Conversely, if one vector is a scalar multiple of the other, say \vec{v}_1 = k \vec{v}_2, then \vec{v}_1 - k \vec{v}_2 = \vec{0}. This is a non-trivial linear combination of \set{\vec{v}_1, \vec{v}_2}, and so \set{\vec{v}_1, \vec{v}_2} is a linearly dependent set.
Geometrically, two vectors are linearly independent if and only if they lie on the same line through the origin.

theorem.p: A set of two vectors \set{\vec{v}_1, \vec{v}_2} is linearly dependent if at least one vector is a scalar multiple of the other. Otherwise, if neither vector is a scalar multiple of the other, then the set is linearly independent.

Then, row reduce the augmented matrix \begin{bmatrix} A \mid \vec{0} \end{bmatrix}. Recall that there is a non-trivial solution if and only if there is a free variable. Thus, in summary,
subsection.theorem: Vectors \vec{v}_1, \dots, \vec{v}_n are linearly independent if and only if the system A\vec{x} = \vec{b} has only the trivial solution, where \vec{v}_1, \dots, \vec{v}_n form the columns of A.
A collection \vec{v}_1, \dots, \vec{v}_n of two or more vectors is linearly dependent if and only if at least one of the vectors can be written as a linear combination of the other vectors.

example.title: Vectors in \mathbb{R}^3
example.p: Consider three vectors \vec{u}, \vec{v}, \vec{w} in \mathbb{R}^3. This set will be linearly dependent if and only if \vec{w} lies in the plane spanned by \vec{u} and \vec{v}.
